title: StatKit
text:
StatKit is a web-based platform for statistical analysis. Upload your CSV data and run tests with just a few clicks.



Upload CSV files - Drag and drop your data
Run statistical tests - T-tests, ANOVA, regression, neural networks
Export results - LaTeX tables, CSV files, model downloads
Explore data - Interactive tables and basic visualizations





Upload your data - CSV files only
Choose a test - Select from available options
Configure parameters - Set variables and options
Run analysis - Get results instantly
Download results - Export in your preferred format






Summarize your data with means, medians, standard deviations, and more.



Compare means between groups: - Independent samples - Paired samples
- One-sample tests



Compare means across multiple groups.



Build predictive models: - Linear regression - Logistic regression



Train machine learning models for classification and regression.





Quick Start Guide - Your first analysis
Statistical Tests - Detailed test guides
FAQ - Common questions
Contact Support - Get help


StatKit is currently in beta. Report issues and provide feedback to help us improve.

title: T-Tests
text:
T-tests compare means between groups to determine if differences are statistically significant.




Compare means between two separate groups.
Example: Compare test scores between students in different schools.
Data Requirements:

Data Column: Numeric variable to compare
Group Column: Categorical variable with exactly 2 groups
Sample Size: At least 2 observations per group




Compare means of related observations.
Example: Before/after treatment measurements.
Data Requirements:

Column 1: First set of measurements
Column 2: Second set of measurements (paired)
Sample Size: At least 2 pairs




Test if a single group differs from a hypothesized value.
Example: Test if a class average differs from the national average.
Data Requirements:

Column: Numeric variable
Population Mean: Hypothesized value (default: 0)
Sample Size: At least 2 observations






Select “T-Test” from the test dropdown
Choose the test type (Independent, Paired, One-sample)
Select your data columns
Click “Run Test”







t-statistic: Measure of difference relative to variability
p-value: Probability of observing this difference by chance
Degrees of Freedom: Number of independent observations
Group Means: Average values for each group





p < 0.05: Generally significant
p < 0.01: Strong significance
p < 0.001: Very strong significance






Normality: Data approximately follows normal distribution
Independence: Observations are independent (except paired tests)
Equal Variance: Groups have similar variability (independent tests)





LaTeX: Copy-paste ready tables
CSV: Structured data files


Need help? Check the FAQ or contact support.

title: Neural Networks
text:
Neural networks are machine learning models that can learn complex patterns in your data for classification and regression tasks.




Predict categories or classes.
Example: Spam vs. not spam, flower species identification.



Predict continuous values.
Example: House prices, stock prices, temperature forecasting.







Numeric features: All input variables must be numeric
Clean data: Remove or handle missing values
Sufficient samples: More data generally leads to better performance





Classification: Categorical variable (2+ classes)
Regression: Continuous numeric variable








Choose “Neural Network” from the test dropdown
Select your CSV file





Task Type: Choose Classification or Regression
Dependent Variable: Select your target variable
Independent Variables: Select one or more feature variables
Hyperparameters (optional):

Hidden Layer Size: Number of neurons (default: 10)
Learning Rate: Step size for training (default: 0.01)
Epochs: Training iterations (default: 1000)





Click “Run Analysis” to train your neural network.







Architecture: Input → Hidden → Output layer sizes
Task Type: Classification or Regression
Hyperparameters: Training configuration used




For Classification:

Accuracy: Percentage of correct predictions
Number of Classes: Total categories in your data

For Regression:

MSE (Mean Squared Error): Average squared prediction error
RMSE (Root Mean Squared Error): Square root of MSE
MAE (Mean Absolute Error): Average absolute prediction error
R²: Proportion of variance explained by the model





Training Loss: Error on training data
Validation Loss: Error on validation data
Convergence: Whether the model stopped improving








Model File (.pkl): Complete trained neural network
Model Info (.json): Architecture and performance details
Python Script: Ready-to-use code for deployment




import numpy as np
import pickle
import base64

# Load your model
model = SimpleNeuralNetwork(input_size, hidden_size, output_size)
model.load_model(model_base64)

# Preprocess new data
normalized_data = preprocess_data(new_data, X_mean, X_std)

# Make predictions
predictions = model.predict(normalized_data)







Clean your data: Remove missing values and outliers
Feature selection: Choose relevant variables
Data splitting: Ensure sufficient training data





Start simple: Use default hyperparameters first
Experiment: Try different hidden layer sizes
Monitor training: Watch for overfitting








Single hidden layer: Limited to one hidden layer
Fixed architecture: Cannot add custom layers
Basic optimization: Uses simple gradient descent





Black-box nature: Difficult to interpret decisions
Data requirements: Need sufficient training data
Computational cost: Training can be time-consuming
Overfitting risk: Can memorize training data






LaTeX: Publication-ready tables
CSV: Structured data format
Model files: Complete models for deployment


Need help? Check the FAQ or contact support.

title: ANOVA
text:
ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) compares means across three or more groups to determine if there are significant differences.



Multiple groups: Compare means across 3+ groups
Categorical predictor: One categorical variable defining groups
Continuous outcome: Numeric variable to compare

Example: Compare test scores across students in different schools.




Outcome Variable: Continuous numeric variable
Group Variable: Categorical variable with 3+ groups
Sample Size: At least 2 observations per group
Independence: Observations are independent





Select “ANOVA” from the test dropdown
Choose your CSV file
Select your outcome variable
Select your group variable
Click “Run Test”







F-statistic: Ratio of between-group to within-group variance
p-value: Probability of observing these differences by chance
Degrees of Freedom: Between and within groups
Group Means: Average values for each group





p < 0.05: At least one group differs significantly
p < 0.01: Strong evidence of differences
p < 0.001: Very strong evidence of differences





Eta-squared: Proportion of variance explained by groups
Large effect: η² > 0.14
Medium effect: η² = 0.06 - 0.14
Small effect: η² < 0.06






Normality: Data approximately follows normal distribution
Independence: Observations are independent
Equal Variance: Groups have similar variability
Random Sampling: Data collected randomly





LaTeX: Copy-paste ready tables
CSV: Structured data files


Need help? Check the FAQ or contact support.

title: Export Formats
text:
StatKit provides multiple export formats to meet different needs for sharing, publishing, and further analysis of your statistical results.





Format: LaTeX code for academic papers
Use case: Publication-ready tables
Features: Professional formatting, mathematical notation
Download: Copy-paste into LaTeX documents





Format: Comma-separated values
Use case: Further analysis in other tools
Features: Structured data, spreadsheet compatible
Download: Direct file download





Format: JavaScript Object Notation
Use case: Programmatic access to results
Features: Complete data structure, API integration
Download: Raw result data





Format: Pickle (.pkl) files
Use case: Model deployment and reuse
Features: Complete trained models, ready for prediction
Download: Binary model files








LaTeX: Publication-ready summary tables
CSV: Structured data with statistics by column
JSON: Complete result data with metadata





LaTeX: Professional statistical tables
CSV: Detailed results with test statistics
JSON: Complete test results and metadata





LaTeX: Analysis of variance tables
CSV: Group comparisons and significance tests
JSON: Complete ANOVA results





LaTeX: Model coefficients and fit statistics
CSV: Regression results and predictions
JSON: Complete model information





LaTeX: Model architecture and performance metrics
CSV: Training results and predictions
JSON: Complete model data
Model File: Trained neural network (.pkl)
Python Script: Ready-to-use deployment code








Run your analysis in StatKit
View results in the dashboard
Choose export format:

Click “Download” for CSV
Copy LaTeX code
Download model files (neural networks)






Navigate to Analyses section
Find your analysis in the list
Click “Download” button
Select format if multiple options available





Open file preview for any dataset
Click “Download” button
File downloads directly to your device








Publication-ready: Professional academic formatting
Mathematical notation: Proper statistical symbols
Table structure: Organized data presentation
Copy-paste: Easy integration into documents




\begin{tabular}{lc}\toprule
Statistic & Value \\ \midrule
Test Type & Independent Samples T-Test \\
Tested Variable & Height \\
Grouping Variable & Gender \\
t-statistic & 2.3456 \\
p-value & 0.023456 \\
Degrees of Freedom & 45.0 \\
Male Mean & 175.2 \\
Female Mean & 162.8 \\
\bottomrule\end{tabular}




Copy the entire table: Include all LaTeX commands
Check formatting: Verify in your LaTeX editor
Customize if needed: Modify for specific journal requirements
Include in document: Paste into your LaTeX file








Structured data: Organized in rows and columns
Spreadsheet compatible: Opens in Excel, Google Sheets
Further analysis: Import into statistical software
Data sharing: Easy to share with colleagues




Statistic,Value
Test Type,Independent Samples T-Test
Tested Variable,Height
Grouping Variable,Gender
t-statistic,2.3456
p-value,0.023456
Degrees of Freedom,45.0
Male Mean,175.2
Female Mean,162.8




Open in spreadsheet: Excel, Google Sheets, or similar
Check formatting: Ensure proper column separation
Further analysis: Import into R, Python, or other tools
Data cleaning: Verify data types and formatting








Complete data: All analysis results included
Programmatic access: Easy to parse with code
Metadata: Additional information about the analysis
API integration: Suitable for automated workflows




{
  "test_type": "Independent Samples T-Test",
  "column1": "Height",
  "column2": "Gender",
  "t_statistic": 2.3456,
  "p_value": 0.023456,
  "df": 45.0,
  "sample1_mean": 175.2,
  "sample2_mean": 162.8,
  "sample1_n": 25,
  "sample2_n": 22
}




Parse with code: Use in Python, R, or JavaScript
Extract specific values: Access individual statistics
Build applications: Integrate into custom tools
Data validation: Verify result structure








Complete model: Trained neural network
Ready for deployment: Load and use immediately
Binary format: Efficient storage and transfer
Python compatible: Works with NumPy and pickle





Ready-to-use code: Complete implementation
Example usage: Shows how to load and use model
Documentation: Includes comments and explanations
Customizable: Easy to modify for your needs





Human-readable: Architecture and performance details
Metadata: Training configuration and results
Documentation: Model specifications and limitations
Sharing: Easy to share model information








Academic papers: Use LaTeX tables
Further analysis: Use CSV or JSON
Model deployment: Use .pkl files
Documentation: Use JSON for metadata





Organize downloads: Create folders for different projects
Version control: Keep track of different analysis runs
Backup important results: Save multiple copies
Naming conventions: Use descriptive file names





Verify downloads: Check file integrity
Test imports: Ensure files work in target applications
Cross-reference: Compare with original results
Document process: Keep notes on export choices








Download fails: Check browser settings and permissions
File corruption: Try downloading again
Format issues: Verify file extension and content
Import problems: Check target application compatibility





Clear browser cache: Remove temporary files
Check file size: Ensure complete download
Verify format: Open file to check content
Try different browser: Use alternative web browser






Understanding Results - Interpreting your analysis
Understanding Results - Interpreting your analysis
Neural Networks - Model downloads


Choose the right export format for your needs. LaTeX for publications, CSV for analysis, JSON for programming, and model files for deployment.

title: FAQ
text:
Visit statisticskit.com and click “Sign In” to create an account.



StatKit supports CSV files only. Use UTF-8 encoding for best results.



Currently no file size limits, but very large files may take longer to process.







Descriptive Statistics
T-Tests (Independent, Paired, One-sample)
ANOVA
Regression (Linear, Logistic)
Neural Networks





Comparing means: T-Tests or ANOVA
Exploring relationships: Regression
Data exploration: Descriptive Statistics
Machine learning: Neural Networks





p < 0.05: Generally significant
p < 0.01: Strong significance
p < 0.001: Very strong significance








LaTeX tables: For academic papers
CSV files: For further analysis
JSON data: For programmatic access
Model files: For neural networks




After running an analysis, click “Download” to get your results.



Yes, all analyses are automatically saved to your account.







Check file format (CSV only)
Verify UTF-8 encoding
Try a smaller file
Check your internet connection




Analysis time depends on:

Data size
Test complexity
Server load





Check your data meets test requirements
Verify file format
Review test parameters
Contact support if needed







Yes, StatKit takes data security seriously:

Encrypted storage
Secure transmission
Access control
Regular backups




Only you can access your data and analyses.

title: Uploading Data
text: Uploading data is the first step in any statistical analysis. StatKit makes it easy to upload your data files and get started with analysis quickly.

title: Uploading Data
text: Uploading data is the first step in any statistical analysis. StatKit makes it easy to upload your data files and get started with analysis quickly.

title: Uploading Data
text:
Supported File Formats

CSV Files (Recommended)

Comma-separated values: Most common format
UTF-8 encoding: Supports international characters
Header row: Column names in the first row
File size: Currently no limits (subject to change)

Related: Data Exploration


Other Formats

Excel files (.xlsx, .xls): Convert to CSV for best results
Text files (.txt): Tab or comma separated
JSON files: Structured data format

title: Uploading Data
text:
Step-by-Step Upload Process

1. Prepare Your Data
Before uploading, ensure your data is ready: - Clean your data: Remove errors and inconsistencies - Check formatting: Ensure proper column headers - Verify data types: Numeric columns should contain numbers - Handle missing values: Decide how to treat missing data
Related: Data Exploration


2. Access the Upload Feature

Sign in to your StatKit account
Navigate to the dashboard
Click “Upload Dataset” button
Select your file from your device



3. File Selection

Browse your computer for the file
Select the file you want to upload
Verify the file name and size
Click “Upload” to proceed



4. Data Preview
After upload, StatKit will: - Display a preview of your data - Show column names and data types - Identify potential issues - Allow you to review before proceeding

title: Uploading Data
text:
Data Requirements

Column Types

Numeric columns: For statistical calculations
Categorical columns: For grouping and comparison
Text columns: For labels and descriptions
Date columns: For time-series analysis



Data Quality

No empty headers: All columns should have names
Consistent formatting: Same data type within columns
Reasonable values: Check for obvious errors
Appropriate sample size: Enough data for meaningful analysis

title: Uploading Data
text:
Common Upload Issues

File Too Large

Issue: File too large for processing
Solution: Consider sampling or reducing file size if needed



Encoding Problems

Issue: Special characters appear incorrectly
Solution: Save file with UTF-8 encoding



Missing Headers

Issue: Column names are missing or unclear
Solution: Add descriptive column names in the first row



Mixed Data Types

Issue: Numeric columns contain text
Solution: Clean data before upload, separate numeric and text columns

title: Uploading Data
text:
Best Practices

Before Upload

Backup your data: Keep original files safe
Document your data: Note what each column represents
Check for errors: Look for obvious mistakes
Consider privacy: Remove sensitive information if needed



During Upload

Use descriptive names: Make column names clear and meaningful
Check preview: Verify data looks correct
Note any warnings: Address issues before analysis
Save metadata: Keep track of data sources and dates



After Upload

Run data quality checks: Use StatKit’s built-in tools
Explore your data: Start with descriptive statistics
Plan your analysis: Decide which tests to run
Document your process: Keep notes for reproducibility

title: Uploading Data
text:
Data Management

Organizing Files

Use clear names: Descriptive file names
Group related data: Keep similar datasets together
Version control: Keep track of different versions
Backup regularly: Don’t rely on cloud storage alone



Updating Data

Replace old files: Upload new versions when data changes
Note changes: Document what was updated
Check compatibility: Ensure new data works with existing analyses
Archive old versions: Keep previous versions for reference

title: About StatKit
text: StatKit is a comprehensive statistical analysis platform designed to make complex statistical tests accessible to researchers, students, and data analysts.

title: About StatKit
text: StatKit is a comprehensive statistical analysis platform designed to make complex statistical tests accessible to researchers, students, and data analysts.

title: About StatKit
text:
Our Mission
We believe that powerful statistical tools should be available to everyone, regardless of their technical background. StatKit provides:

User-friendly interfaces for complex statistical procedures
Publication-ready outputs for academic and professional use
Educational resources to help users understand statistical concepts
Reliable results using proven statistical methods

title: About StatKit
text:
What We Offer

Statistical Tests

Descriptive Statistics: Explore and summarize your data
T-Tests: Compare means between groups or against hypothesized values
ANOVA: Compare means across multiple groups
Regression Analysis: Build predictive models with linear and logistic regression



Key Features

Web-based Interface: No software installation required
Real-time Results: Fast processing and immediate feedback
Multiple Export Formats: LaTeX tables, CSV files, and JSON data
Mobile Responsive: Works on all devices
Secure Data Handling: Your data is protected

title: About StatKit
text:
Development Status
StatKit is currently in beta development. We’re actively improving the platform based on user feedback and adding new features.

text:
Get Started
Ready to try StatKit? Visit our platform to start your first analysis.

Contact & Support

Documentation: This site

StatKit - Making statistical analysis accessible to everyone.

title: Data Exploration
text:
StatKit’s data exploration feature allows you to interactively analyze and visualize your data before running statistical tests. This powerful tool helps you understand your data structure, identify patterns, and prepare for analysis.


The data explorer provides a comprehensive interface for: - Data preview: View your data in a paginated table - Filtering: Apply filters to focus on specific data subsets - Visualization: Create basic charts and graphs - Summary statistics: Get quick insights about your data






Upload your CSV file
Click “Preview” on any dataset
Click “Explore Data” button (appears for CSV files)
The data explorer modal will open







Pagination: Navigate through large datasets
Column selection: Show/hide specific columns
Sorting: Click column headers to sort
Search: Find specific values quickly





Equals: Exact value matching
Contains: Text search within values
Greater/Less than: Numeric comparisons
Between: Range filtering for numeric data
In list: Multiple value selection





Histograms: Distribution of numeric variables
Scatter plots: Relationship between two variables
Bar charts: Frequency of categorical variables
Box plots: Distribution and outliers





Numeric variables: Mean, median, min, max, standard deviation
Categorical variables: Count, unique values, most common
Data quality: Missing values, data types









Navigate to your uploaded CSV file
Click “Preview” to view the file
Click “Explore Data” button
The explorer opens in a modal window




The explorer has three main views:



View your data: Browse through rows and columns
Select columns: Choose which variables to display
Pagination: Navigate large datasets efficiently
Export filtered data: Download filtered results





Select chart type: Histogram, scatter, bar, or box plot
Choose variables: Pick X and Y axes for visualizations
Interpret results: Understand data distributions and relationships





Variable overview: Statistics for each column
Data quality: Missing values and data types
Quick insights: Key characteristics of your data






Click “Add Filter” button
Select the column to filter
Choose the filter operator
Enter filter values
Click “Add Filter” to apply





Review filtered data: See how filters affect your dataset
Check visualizations: Understand data patterns
Note insights: Document important findings
Prepare for analysis: Use insights to choose appropriate tests








Equals: Exact numeric match
Greater than: Values above threshold
Less than: Values below threshold
Between: Values within range





Equals: Exact text match
Contains: Text search (case-insensitive)
In list: Multiple value selection





Multiple filters: Combine different conditions
Clear filters: Remove all filters at once
Filter persistence: Filters remain active across views








Purpose: Show distribution of numeric variables
Use when: Understanding data spread and shape
Interpretation: Look for normal distribution, skewness, outliers





Purpose: Show relationship between two numeric variables
Use when: Investigating correlations or patterns
Interpretation: Look for linear relationships, clusters, outliers





Purpose: Show frequency of categorical variables
Use when: Understanding category distributions
Interpretation: Identify most/least common categories





Purpose: Show distribution and identify outliers
Use when: Understanding data spread and detecting anomalies
Interpretation: Look for symmetry, outliers, data range








Check for missing values: Identify incomplete data
Verify data types: Ensure numeric variables are properly formatted
Look for outliers: Identify unusual values that might affect analysis
Assess sample size: Ensure sufficient data for statistical tests





Start with summary: Get overview of all variables
Examine distributions: Use histograms for numeric data
Check relationships: Use scatter plots for correlations
Apply filters: Focus on relevant data subsets
Document findings: Note important patterns and issues





Choose appropriate tests: Use insights to select statistical methods
Handle missing data: Decide how to treat incomplete observations
Consider transformations: Note if data needs normalization
Plan follow-up: Identify additional analyses needed
Evaluate ML potential: Consider neural networks for complex patterns








Literature review: Understand previous findings
Hypothesis generation: Identify potential relationships
Method selection: Choose appropriate statistical tests
Quality assurance: Verify data integrity





Customer segmentation: Identify distinct groups
Trend analysis: Spot patterns over time
Performance monitoring: Track key metrics
Decision support: Inform business strategies





Learning tool: Understand statistical concepts
Data storytelling: Present findings clearly
Method practice: Apply statistical techniques
Report preparation: Generate insights for reports








Basic visualizations: Limited to fundamental chart types
Single dataset: Cannot compare multiple files
No advanced analytics: Focus on exploration, not modeling
Export limitations: Filtered data only
ML preparation: Data exploration helps prepare for neural network analysis





Large datasets: Performance may slow with very large files
Memory usage: Very large datasets may cause browser issues
Mobile compatibility: Best experience on desktop








Start broad: Begin with summary statistics
Focus gradually: Apply filters to narrow scope
Document process: Keep notes of your exploration
Save insights: Export important findings





Slow performance: Try filtering to smaller datasets
Missing visualizations: Ensure data types are appropriate
Filter issues: Check data format and values
Export problems: Verify file permissions

title: Getting Started
text:
Follow these simple steps to run your first statistical analysis.



Sign in to your StatKit account
Click “Upload Dataset”
Select your CSV file
Review the data preview




Format: CSV files only
Encoding: UTF-8 recommended
Header: First row should contain column names
Data: Numeric columns for statistical tests





Select from available statistical tests:


Summarize your data with basic statistics.



Compare means between groups:

Independent: Two separate groups
Paired: Related measurements
One-sample: Test against a value




Compare means across multiple groups.



Build predictive models:

Linear: Predict continuous values
Logistic: Predict categories




Train machine learning models for classification and regression.





Select your dependent variable
Choose independent variables
Set any additional options
Click “Run Analysis”




Results include:

Statistical test output
P-values and significance
Effect sizes
Descriptive statistics




Download your results in:

LaTeX: For academic papers
CSV: For further analysis
JSON: For programmatic access
Model files: For neural networks





Start with descriptive statistics to understand your data
Check that your data meets test requirements
Save important results
Cross-check with other software if needed





FAQ - Common questions

title: Understanding Results
text: Understanding your statistical results is crucial for drawing meaningful conclusions from your data. This guide will help you interpret the output from StatKit’s various statistical tests.

title: Understanding Results
text: Understanding your statistical results is crucial for drawing meaningful conclusions from your data. This guide will help you interpret the output from StatKit’s various statistical tests.

title: Understanding Results
text:
Key Concepts

Statistical Significance

p-value: Probability of observing results by chance
Alpha level: Threshold for significance (typically 0.05)
Effect size: Practical importance of the result
Confidence intervals: Range of likely true values



Effect Sizes

Small effect: Noticeable but not practically important
Medium effect: Moderate practical importance
Large effect: Substantial practical importance

title: Understanding Results
text:
Understanding Different Test Results

Descriptive Statistics
What you get: - Measures of central tendency: Mean, median, mode - Measures of variability: Standard deviation, variance, range - Distribution shape: Skewness, kurtosis - Sample size: Number of observations
How to interpret: - Mean vs Median: Compare to understand skewness - Standard deviation: Higher values indicate more spread - Range: Difference between minimum and maximum
Related: Descriptive Statistics


T-Test Results
What you get: - t-statistic: Measure of difference relative to variability - p-value: Probability of observing this difference by chance - Degrees of freedom: Number of independent observations - Group means: Average values for each group - Effect size: Practical importance of the difference
How to interpret: - p < 0.05: Statistically significant difference - t-statistic: Larger absolute values indicate bigger differences - Effect size: Consider practical significance beyond statistical significance
Related: T-Tests


ANOVA Results
What you get: - F-statistic: Ratio of between-group to within-group variance - p-value: Probability of observing these differences by chance - Degrees of freedom: Between and within groups - Group means: Average values for each group - Effect size: Proportion of variance explained
How to interpret: - p < 0.05: At least one group differs significantly - F-statistic: Larger values indicate bigger differences - Post-hoc tests: Identify which specific groups differ
Related: ANOVA


Regression Results
What you get: - R-squared: Proportion of variance explained by the model - Coefficients: Change in dependent variable per unit change in predictor - p-values: Statistical significance of each predictor - Standard errors: Uncertainty in coefficient estimates - Model fit statistics: Overall model performance
How to interpret: - R-squared: Higher values indicate better model fit - Coefficients: Direction and magnitude of relationships - p-values: Which predictors are statistically significant
Related: Regression Analysis


Neural Network Results
What you get: - Model architecture: Input, hidden, and output layer sizes - Task type: Classification or regression - Performance metrics: Accuracy (classification) or MSE/R² (regression) - Training progress: Loss values and convergence - Model download: Complete trained model for deployment
How to interpret: - Accuracy: Higher values indicate better classification performance - MSE/RMSE: Lower values indicate better regression predictions - Training loss: Should decrease and stabilize during training - Model complexity: Balance between performance and interpretability
Related: Neural Networks

title: Understanding Results
text:
Reading Output Tables

Table Structure
Most StatKit results include: - Variable names: What was tested - Test statistics: Calculated values (t, F, etc.) - p-values: Statistical significance - Effect sizes: Practical importance - Descriptive statistics: Means, standard deviations


Formatting

Bold values: Often indicate significance
**Asterisks (*)**: Mark significant results
Decimal places: Precision of estimates
Units: Scale of measurement

title: Understanding Results
text:
Common Interpretation Mistakes

P-Value Misconceptions

Mistake: “p = 0.04 means 96% chance the result is true”
Reality: p-value is probability of data given null hypothesis, not probability of hypothesis given data



Effect Size Neglect

Mistake: Focusing only on statistical significance
Reality: Consider practical importance of the effect



Multiple Testing

Mistake: Running many tests without adjusting significance levels
Reality: Multiple comparisons increase chance of false positives



Correlation vs Causation

Mistake: Assuming significant correlation means causation
Reality: Correlation doesn’t imply causation

title: Understanding Results
text:
Best Practices

Before Analysis

Define hypotheses: What do you expect to find?
Choose appropriate tests: Match test to your data and question
Set significance level: Decide on alpha before analysis
Plan sample size: Ensure adequate power



During Analysis

Check assumptions: Ensure test requirements are met
Look at effect sizes: Don’t just focus on p-values
Consider practical significance: Is the effect meaningful?
Document your process: Keep notes for reproducibility



After Analysis

Interpret in context: Consider your research question
Report effect sizes: Include practical importance
Acknowledge limitations: Be honest about what you can’t conclude
Plan follow-up: What questions remain?

title: Understanding Results
text:
Exporting and Sharing Results

Export Formats

LaTeX tables: For academic papers
CSV files: For further analysis
JSON data: For programmatic access
Model files: Trained neural networks for deployment

Related: Export Formats


Reporting Guidelines

Include effect sizes: Don’t just report p-values
Provide context: Explain what the results mean
Acknowledge limitations: Be transparent about assumptions
Use appropriate precision: Don’t overstate precision

title: Understanding Results
text:
Related Topics

Export Formats - Sharing your results
Export Formats - Downloading your results
FAQ - Common questions and answers
FAQ - Common questions and answers

title: Understanding Results
text:
Next Steps
After understanding your results: 1. Document your findings - Write clear interpretations 2. Share your results - Export in appropriate formats 3. Plan follow-up analyses - Address remaining questions 4. Consider implications - What do your results mean for your field?

Need help interpreting specific results? Check our FAQ or contact support.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Descriptive statistics summarize and explore your data with basic statistical measures.





Mean: Arithmetic average
Median: Middle value
Mode: Most frequent value





Standard Deviation: Average distance from mean
Variance: Square of standard deviation
Range: Difference between min and max
Min/Max: Smallest and largest values





Skewness: Measure of asymmetry
Kurtosis: Measure of peakedness






Numeric variables: For statistical calculations
Sample size: At least 2 observations
Missing data: Automatically excluded





Select “Descriptive Statistics” from the test dropdown
Choose your CSV file
Select numeric columns to analyze
Click “Run Test”







Mean vs Median: Compare to understand skewness
Standard deviation: Higher values indicate more spread
Range: Shows the full spread of your data





Normal distribution: Mean ≈ median, symmetric
Skewed data: Mean ≠ median, asymmetric
Outliers: Values far from the rest






LaTeX: Copy-paste ready tables
CSV: Structured data files


Need help? Check the FAQ or contact support.

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:
Mean: Arithmetic average
Median: Middle value
Mode: Most frequent value





Standard Deviation: Average distance from mean
Variance: Square of standard deviation
Range: Difference between min and max
Min/Max: Smallest and largest values





Skewness: Measure of asymmetry
Kurtosis: Measure of peakedness

title: Descriptive Statistics
text:

title: Regression
text:
Regression models predict outcomes based on input variables. StatKit supports linear and logistic regression.




Predict continuous outcomes.
Example: Predict house prices based on size, location, age.



Predict binary outcomes.
Example: Predict whether a customer will buy (yes/no) based on demographics.







Dependent Variable: Continuous numeric outcome
Independent Variables: One or more numeric predictors
Sample Size: At least n+1 observations (where n = number of predictors)





Dependent Variable: Binary or categorical with exactly 2 values
Independent Variables: One or more numeric or categorical predictors
Sample Size: At least n+1 observations per category






Select “Regression” from the test dropdown
Choose your CSV file
Select your dependent variable
Choose independent variables
Click “Run Test”







R-squared: Proportion of variance explained (0 to 1)
RMSE: Root Mean Square Error - prediction accuracy
Coefficients: Change in outcome per unit change in predictor
P-values: Statistical significance of predictors





Pseudo R-squared: Measure of model fit
Coefficients: Change in log-odds per unit change in predictor
P-values: Statistical significance of predictors





Linear: Higher R-squared indicates better fit
Logistic: Higher pseudo R-squared indicates better fit
P-values: < 0.05 indicates significant predictors








Linearity: Relationship between variables is linear
Independence: Observations are independent
Homoscedasticity: Constant variance of residuals
Normality: Residuals are normally distributed





Independence: Observations are independent
No multicollinearity: Predictors are not highly correlated
Large sample size: At least 10 events per predictor






LaTeX: Copy-paste ready tables
CSV: Structured data files


Need help? Check the FAQ or contact support.

Sample Size: At least n+1 observations (where n = number of predictors)

title: Exploratory Analysis
text: Exploratory analysis is the first step in any statistical investigation. It helps you understand your data’s structure, identify patterns, and detect potential issues before running formal statistical tests.

title: Exploratory Analysis
text: Exploratory analysis is the first step in any statistical investigation. It helps you understand your data’s structure, identify patterns, and detect potential issues before running formal statistical tests.

title: Exploratory Analysis
text:
What is Exploratory Analysis?
Exploratory analysis involves: - Data summarization: Understanding central tendencies and variability - Pattern identification: Finding trends, outliers, and relationships - Data quality assessment: Checking for missing values, errors, and inconsistencies - Distribution analysis: Understanding how your data is distributed

title: Exploratory Analysis
text:
Available Tools in StatKit

Descriptive Statistics
The foundation of exploratory analysis. Use this to: - Calculate means, medians, standard deviations - Identify minimum and maximum values - Understand data distributions - Check for outliers
Related: Descriptive Statistics


Data Quality Checks
Before running any analysis, ensure your data is clean: - Check for missing values - Identify data types - Verify data ranges - Look for inconsistencies
Related: Data Exploration

title: Exploratory Analysis
text:
When to Use Exploratory Analysis

Always Start Here

New datasets: Understand what you’re working with
Data cleaning: Identify issues before analysis
Hypothesis generation: Discover patterns that suggest further testing
Quality control: Ensure data meets assumptions



Specific Use Cases

Academic research: Preliminary data exploration
Business analytics: Understanding customer behavior patterns
Student projects: Learning data analysis fundamentals
Data exploration: Discovering insights in large datasets

title: Exploratory Analysis
text:
Step-by-Step Process

1. Upload Your Data
Start by uploading your CSV file to StatKit.
Related: Uploading Data


2. Run Descriptive Statistics
Select multiple variables to get a comprehensive overview: - Numeric variables: Means, medians, standard deviations - Categorical variables: Frequency counts - Multiple variables: Compare distributions across groups


3. Interpret Results
Look for: - Central tendency: Where most values cluster - Variability: How spread out the data is - Skewness: Whether data is symmetric or skewed - Outliers: Unusual values that might need attention


4. Plan Next Steps
Based on your findings: - Clean data if needed - Choose appropriate tests for your research questions - Consider transformations for skewed data - Design follow-up analyses

title: Exploratory Analysis
text:
Best Practices

Data Visualization

Always visualize your data when possible
Look for patterns, trends, and outliers
Consider different chart types for different data types



Multiple Perspectives

Examine data from different angles
Consider different groupings and subsets
Look for relationships between variables



Documentation

Keep notes on your findings
Document any data cleaning steps
Record insights for future reference

title: Exploratory Analysis
text:
Common Issues and Solutions

Missing Data

Issue: Incomplete datasets
Solution: Use StatKit’s data quality checks to identify missing values



Outliers

Issue: Extreme values affecting analysis
Solution: Examine outliers carefully - they might be errors or important findings



Non-normal Distributions

Issue: Data doesn’t follow normal distribution
Solution: Consider data transformations or non-parametric tests

Next Steps
After completing exploratory analysis: 1. Clean your data if issues were found 2. Choose appropriate statistical tests based on your findings 3. Run formal analyses to test your hypotheses 4. Document your process for reproducibility
